newsitem.title: USA: Aetna earnings beat analyst forecast, stock soars.
newsitem.headline: Aetna earnings beat analyst forecast, stock soars.

text.p: Aetna Inc. reported higher-than-expected first-quarter profits Tuesday due to growth in all three of the health insurance giant's main business areas, triggering a jump in its stock.
The Hartford, Conn.-based company's net income was $279.3 million, or $1.85 a share, compared with $347.7 million, or $3 a share, in the first quarter of 1996.

Operating earnings, however, increased to $186.8 million, or $1.14 a share, from $165.5 million, or $1.07 a share, and beat the First Call service's consensus Wall Street analyst forecast for $1.05 a share. First quarter 1996 operating earnings excluded health maintenance organisation U.S. Healthcare, which Aetna acquired last July 1996.
Revenues reflected the acquisition, increasing 34 percent to $4.49 billion from $3.34 billion in the year-ago period, Aetna said.

Aetna reported its earnings before financial markets opened. Following a brief delay due to a trading imbalance, the stock surged, rising $5.75 to $96.375 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Our efforts to reposition Aetna began to pay off in the first quarter of 1997," Aetna Chairman Ronald Compton said in a statement.
"Earnings from all three of our core businesses -- health, retirement services and international -- grew at double-digit rates from the prior-year quarter," he said.
Aetna U.S. Healthcare, the company's health insurance arm, reported $140.6 million in operating earnings after a $74.4 million charge, compared with $79.9 million a year ago.
"Aetna U.S. Healthcare significantly lowered operating expenses" due to changes made last year, Compton said.

Aetna Retirement Services -- which sells life insurance as well as annuities and other retirement and investment products -- posted operating earnings of $52.9 million, up 14 percent from $46.3 million in 1996.

Aetna International, which primarily sells life insurance as well as health and financial services products in emerging markets, also saw a 14 percent rise in operating earnings, to $27.5 million from $24.1 million.
